Share: Digg Facebook StumbleUpon Part 3: Silbury Hill “Quetzlcoatl Headdress” First Filmed At Dawn © 2009 by Linda Moulton Howe T he reddish iris on the map marks the position of 5,000-year-old Silbury Hill that rises 130 feet above the land on the north side of the Roman Road. Across the road to the south, the topography rises to another hill nearly as high as Silbury Hill. The 350-foot-diameter “Quetzalcoatl Headdress” is marked by the green circle. R eturn to Part 1 August 18, 2009 Albuquerque, New Mexico - While I was in England July 24 to August 11, 2009, I met Ryan O'Hara, cameraman working with a documentary film crew that had been doing a night watch on top of 5,000-year-old Silbury Hill from 3 AM to dawn in the early morning hours of July 5. As the sunset turned to darkness on July 4th around 10 PM, no one amid all the air traffic over the ancient Avebury and Silbury complex had reported any new formation across the road from the 130-foot-tall Silbury Hill. But near 4:15 AM, cameraman Ryan O'Hara spotted a shadowy line in the hilltop wheat field south of Silbury Hill and the Roman Road and ran his visible light camera in the pre-dawn. He gave me permission to reprint his first greenish image, followed by more detail as dawn light increased to first sunrise images when the heavy dew sparkled undisturbed without any human presence in the wheat.
“Quetzalcoatl Headdress” Atop Wheat Field Across Road from Silbury Hill

“Q uetzalcoatl Headdress” about 350 feet in diameter first discovered July 5, 2009, around 4:15 AM by documentary film crew that camped from 3:00 AM onward atop Silbury Hill on the north side of the Roman Road separating Silbury and the hilltop wheat field. Aerial image © 2009 by Jack Roderick. For other images and information: Cropcircle conne ctor.
